metadata.title: NSLayoutGuide | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Official Apple Developer Documentation for NSLayoutGuide, a class that defines a rectangular area that can interact with Auto Layout. The document explains how layout guides replace placeholder views for defining spacing and encapsulation in user interfaces, providing a more efficient and safer alternative.

content.text: A rectangular area that can interact with Auto Layout.

Use layout guides to replace the placeholder views you may have created to represent interview spaces or encapsulation in your user interface. Traditionally, there were a number of Auto Layout techniques that required placeholder views. A placeholder view is an empty view that does not have any visual elements of its own and serves only to define a rectangular region in the view hierarchy. For example, if you wanted to use constraints to define the size or location of an empty space between views, you needed to use a placeholder view to represent that space. If you wanted to center a group of objects, you needed a placeholder view to contain those objects. Similarly, placeholder views could be used to contain and encapsulate part of your user interface. Placeholder views let you break up a large, complex user interface into self-contained, modular chunks. When used properly, they could greatly simplify your Auto Layout constraint logic.

There are a number of costs associated with adding placeholder views to your view hierarchy. First, there is the cost of creating and maintaining the view itself. Second, the placeholder view is a full member of the view hierarchy, which means that it adds overhead to every task the hierarchy performs. Worst of all, the invisible placeholder view can intercept messages that are intended for other views, causing problems that are very difficult to find.

The NSLayoutGuide class is designed to perform all the tasks previously performed by placeholder views, but to do it in a safer, more efficient manner. Layout guides are not views. They do not use as much memory, and they do not participate in the view hierarchy. Instead, they simply define a rectangular region in their owning view's coordinate system that can interact with Auto Layout.
To create a layout guide, perform the following steps:

items.text: Add the layout guide to a view by calling the view's addLayoutGuide(_:) method.
Define the position and size of the layout guide using Auto Layout.

content.text: You can use these guides to define the space between elements in your layout. The following example shows how to use layout guides to define an equal spacing between a series of views.

content.code:
let space1 = NSLayoutGuide()
view.addLayoutGuide(space1)

let space2 = NSLayoutGuide()
view.addLayoutGuide(space2)

space1.widthAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(space2.widthAnchor).active = true
saveButton.trailingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(space1.leadingAnchor).active = true
cancelButton.leadingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(space1.trailingAnchor).active = true
cancelButton.trailingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(space2.leadingAnchor).active = true
clearButton.leadingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(space2.trailingAnchor).active = true

content.text: A layout guide can also act as an opaque box that contains other views and controls, letting you encapsulate parts of your view and break up your layout into modular chunks.

content.code:
let container = NSLayoutGuide()
view.addLayoutGuide(container)

// Layout the contents of the container
button.lastBaselineAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(textField.lastBaselineAnchor).active = true
button.leadingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(container.leadingAnchor).active = true
textField.leadingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(button.trailingAnchor, constant: 8.0).active = true
textField.trailingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(container.trailingAnchor).active = true
textField.topAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(container.topAnchor).active = true
textField.bottomAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(container.bottomAnchor).active = true

// Set exterior constraints.
container.leadingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(margins.leadingAnchor).active = true
container.trailingAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(margins.trailingAnchor).active = true
container.topAnchor.constraintEqualToAnchor(margins.topAnchor).active = true

comments.text: // Layout the contents of the container

content.title: Note
content.text: Layout constraints do not fully encapsulate their contents. The system still compares the priority of optional constraints inside the layout guide with the priority of optional constraints outside the guide.

pages.pageSummary: This page documents NSLayoutGuide, an AppKit class for macOS 10.11+ that provides a rectangular area for Auto Layout constraints without the overhead of placeholder views. It covers the class overview, how to create layout guides, code examples for equal spacing and encapsulation patterns, all available anchor properties (leading, trailing, top, bottom, center, width, height), instance properties and methods, class relationships (inherits from NSObject, conforms to multiple protocols), and related classes.

sections.title: Overview
sections.summary: Explains the purpose of NSLayoutGuide as a replacement for placeholder views in Auto Layout, describing the problems with placeholder views (memory overhead, view hierarchy participation, message interception) and how layout guides solve these issues.

sections.title: Creating Layout Guides
sections.summary: Provides step-by-step instructions for creating layout guides and includes two Swift code examples: one for creating equal spacing between buttons, and another for using a layout guide as a container to encapsulate views.

subsections.title: Creating Constraints Using Layout Anchors

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard API documentation structure: it begins with a class declaration and brief description, provides conceptual overview explaining the problem being solved and the solution approach, gives practical code examples, then presents comprehensive API reference organized by topic (properties, methods, anchors), and concludes with class relationships and related APIs.

keyTerms.definition: A rectangular area that can interact with Auto Layout without being a view in the view hierarchy.
An empty view with no visual elements that serves only to define a rectangular region in the view hierarchy for Auto Layout purposes.
Apple's constraint-based layout system for defining UI element positions and sizes.
A factory object for creating layout constraints using a fluent API (e.g., leadingAnchor, trailingAnchor).
The tree structure of views in an application where each view can have subviews.
The practice of grouping related views together using a container (layout guide or view) to create modular UI chunks.
A factory class for creating size-based layout constraint objects using a fluent API.
A layout anchor representing a horizontal position (leading, trailing, left, right, centerX).
A layout anchor representing a vertical position (top, bottom, centerY).

keyFindings: NSLayoutGuide provides all functionality of placeholder views without the overhead of being in the view hierarchy.
Layout guides do not intercept touch/click events like placeholder views can, avoiding hard-to-debug issues.
Layout guides use less memory than equivalent placeholder views.
Layout guides can define spacing between elements or act as containers to encapsulate groups of views.
Layout constraints inside a layout guide are NOT fully encapsulated - their priorities are still compared with constraints outside the guide.
To create a layout guide: instantiate it, add to a view with addLayoutGuide(_:), then define position/size with Auto Layout constraints.

designDecisions.decision: Use NSLayoutGuide instead of placeholder UIView/NSView for spacing and encapsulation
designDecisions.rationale: Reduces memory usage, removes view hierarchy overhead, prevents accidental event interception

designDecisions.decision: Layout guides define regions in owning view's coordinate system
designDecisions.rationale: Allows integration with Auto Layout without requiring view hierarchy participation

designDecisions.decision: Provide both left/right and leading/trailing anchors
designDecisions.rationale: Supports both absolute positioning (left/right) and internationalization-aware positioning (leading/trailing for RTL languages)
